								Don't think about it, just give this game a chance. It's free, if you don't like it, just uninstall it.This game is one of the coolest most interesting concepts for a game I've seen in the past decade.I'm not going to compare this game to a MOBA or Twisted metal which is what every single review of this game does, instead I'm going to describe it all on it's own.Heavy Metal Machines is a 4vs4 team based Battle Racing game. There is one simple objective, capture the bomb from the center of the map, and deliver it to the enemy's base, but it's not as simple as it sounds. Each team has their own race track on their side of the map that the enemy team has to transport the bomb through and your job is to stop them from getting there, intercept the bomb from them, and turn around to race it to their side of the map. With a plentyful roster of drivers with their own unique vehicles to choose from, you build a team of 4 with each player trying to fill one of 3 roles, Transporter, Interceptor, and Support.The Transporter's skill set revolves around mobility and keeping posession of the bomb while "transporting" it to the enemy base.As an Interceptor, you will be dealing damage to the enemy team's vehicles in an attempt to protect your bomb carrier, as well as taking theirs out.And last but not least, The Support class is very important, you'll be shielding, healing, and dishing out crowd control to make sure your team delivers the bomb without a hitch, it's an invaluable role as well as a very satisfying and fun role to play.Imagine a scene from Fast and Furious or Mad Max where a convoy of vehicles is battling it out for control of a precious cargo, that's what this game feels like, and it is just as awesome as it sounds.Give this game a shot, you won't regret it.

								Heavy Metal Machines Open Beta Review!The beautifully stylized, adrenaline packed world of Heavy Metal Machines (HMM) reinvigorates the Automotive Battle Arena genre. The beta took me back to the hay day of the Twisted Metal and Vigilante 8 franchises while older players will recall Rock n’ Roll racing and Combat Cars as more direct sources of inspiration for HMM. Veteran developer, Hoplon Infotainment, may be better known in Latin America having released games like Taikodom and Apocalypse: Party's Over from its offices in the incredibly beautiful Florianópolis, Brazil. HMM is intended to be a global affair with servers located in North America, South America, Europe, and most recently Asia. I expect this title to develop a robust competitive scene of 4 vs. 4 bomb delivery action (more on that below) as players in the beta are already quite competitive and are chatting away in the Heavy Metal Machines forums.The ArtI don’t usually start with the art work in a game but it's impossible to ignore the cohesive, hyper stylized world inside the walls of Metal City. The artwork is a wicked fusion of Mad Max and Darkest Dungeon tones blended with a darker version of the DC Comic's color pallet. The game has a ominous appeal to it, but not in a depressing way. Metal City is gloomy and damp, anchored by blues and purples but is splashed with the bright yellows and reds of lava and fire.While we will discuss the characters more below they are heavily stylized in their appearance which is consistently complimented by the machines they drive, abilities they use, and music they rock out too.The art work alone could sell Heavy Metal Machines for many gamers and is sure to catch people’s attention like it did on the floor of Twitch Con 2016 which I where I met the Hoplon road team.Game PlayElegant simplicity of objective and control scheme make this title easy to pick up while skill shot based abilities and fast moving vehicle action make it hard to master, exactly what you want in a competitive team game. While you can play with a controller, I haven’t tried it yet, so I can only discuss the mouse and key board controls. Holding down Left Mouse Button accelerates the car forward, Right Mouse Button flips the car around to drive in reverse, Q and W pop your basic abilities, R pops your character’s ultimate ability, and E gives you a burst of speed. Most (if not all) of the abilities have fairly standard cooldown mechanics that any MOBA or MMO player will be familiar with. Your ultimate must be charged up by dealing out damage or healing your friends so creating chaos for the opponent is reward by allowing you to create more chaos! Nice!The core game mode is a 4 vs. 4 bomb grab and delivery arena. A bomb spawns in the center of the map and teams charge into battle, grab the bomb, and attempt to drive it to their opponent's spawn location. You are free to drive almost anywhere on the large, symmetric map unless you are carrying the bomb which forces you to follow a longer, winding path. Tight turns, pools of lava, and zones that will knock the bomb out of your possession demand skilled driving. The other players are unencumbered by the bomb allowing them to cut corners and zip through short cuts ensuring they can catch up to the bomb carrier forcing high speed team fighting and chaotic offensive or evasive driving depending on your role. Scoring the bomb three times will result in a win!During game play you can earn "Metal" by beating up on the opposition that allow you to buff your vehicle and its abilities in various ways. You can pick from an assortment of generic boosts like additional health and higher damage or you can directly boost the effectiveness of your abilities. These customization options only last for a single match meaning that you can experiment with different builds and adapt your build to counter the bad guys or compliment your friends.More recently an in game VoIP has been added WHICH I LOVE. I can’t stress this enough, yes it leads to people flaming, yes you will have mic trolls, and soundboards can be annoying (or really awesome if done well) BUT nothing showcases a community's culture or encourages competitive play like VoIP in game. I’ve spent way too many hours playing Counter Strike and I firmly believe the allowing for mic communication in game is a core reason that the Counter Strike franchise has had so much staying power in the eSports universe. Players can strategize, communicate on a deeper level, and even when players are being salty, VoIP can encourage a competitive culture that drives eSports participation in a game. There have been complaints about flaming and mic spamming (I have been flamed on stream) but I think the benefits of open, in game VoIP far out weight the costs in a game built for competition like Heavy Metal Machines.CharactersThe motif of a Gwar Concert meets Mad Max Fury Road and what must have been a comic book obsessed art team to create the Metal Heads that populate Heavy Metal Machines' Character selection screen. Every character has a story, style, and sound track with move sets that compliment their personalities. Run the bomb to its final destination with a speed metal obsessed "transporter" class or knock your opponents off course with crowd control heavy "interceptors". Feeling like more of a soft rock fan? That's ok, HMM has support characters that allow you to heal friends, debuff bad guys, and out right silence the enemy jam session. My favorite Character at the moment is Full Metal Judge, technically an interceptor, FMJ can lay down the damage with a front mounted gatling gun while pulling away from the pack with a ramming ability that doubles as a speed boost. Worth mentioning that I haven't tried out Killer J, a clown of questionable morals, who was released in a recent patch. CriticismThe VoIP could be open during the character select screen so that teams could more easily communicate composition and character selection.Players dropping from matches leading to unbalanced 3v4 (or worse) fight. I wont comment on this much since Hoplon has already addressed it in a recent post. The gist is that players are dropping from matches more frequently than expected and the game does not attempt to replace the lost player at this point.While simplicity of objective and the games easy to grasp control scheme are some of the game’s greatest strengths they do create a depth of content issue. After testing out a few characters you’ll eventually find a character you resonate with and likely stick to them as you grind your fame up and level up the driver to unlock new skins. Once you complete your daily quests it’s the same map and game mode over and over again. The ability to upgrade cars in match can break this up if you are willing to experiment with builds but this can only go so far. What the game could use at a minimum are additional maps or possibly some additional game modes. Hoplon has already addressed some of these concerns in a recent post stating that "our main – competitive – game mode is the bomb delivery. Which does not mean that we will not build other modes or that the current map will be the only one ever. We fully plan in adding more maps for the bomb mode, and – eventually – adding different modes altogether.".Some of the abilities are meant to be held down as opposed to pressing and quickly releasing the button associated with an ability. If a player actually reads the tool tip this is pretty obvious but assuming that most players don’t actually read menus there may be a UI change that could make this game mechanic more obvious to new players.Review was originally posted to http://www.infirmarygaming.com/articles/news/general/58/game-review-heavy-metal-machines-beta/In full disclosure Hoplon has provided DLC content to the Infirmary Gaming Community which I manage and write for.

								This is a fantastic mashup between Twisted Metal and Rock N Roll Racing all folded into a MOBA format.  The game is 4 v 4 Bomb Run, which pits playes in a symmetrical arena with mini race tracks on either side.  The bomb spawns in the middle and the teams fight to carry the bomb through the opposing team's track and into their goal.  There are three classes: transporter, support and interceptor.  Transporters specialize in moving the ball, interceptors specialize in damage and crowd control while support specializes in heals and crowd control.  The first time I played it, I honestly thought it was a frantic mess.  Ten games later, I'm strategizing with my friends over team comp, devising new ambushes and learning to drive backwards while carrying the ball and fighting off enemies.  The game offers surprising depth and competition, while the devs have already promised new modes which all sound amazing.  I'd say the only thing the game currently lacks is a playerbase, so hop on in!

								Remember Rock N' Roll racing on the Sega Genesis? It's like that, but a 1000 times better. If you weren't alive to play video games in the 90's, Heavy Metal Machines is a 4v4 fight over a single bomb that has to be delivered to the enemies goal. You have different classes of cars to choose from. Healers that heal, interceptors that fight, and transporters that are good at moving the bomb. Each match lets you buy upgrades specific to your character, things like extra damage from your Q attack or faster nitro cooldown. Teamwork is important, as you can pass the bomb to another teammate if you need to. Teammates also have to help heal you and peel off the enemy as they try to stop you from delivering the bomb. The 1 level you play on has hazards that can pop the ball off the carrier or just destroy a vehicle in lava which adds extra strategy.Pros - Fun, and unique gameplay        - Car choices are varied and all have different strengths and weaknesses        - Announcer and character voices are great. At respawn a certain character might say "Witness me!"        - Graphics are good and the game runs in 4k for me on my 1070        - Mouse controls work wellCons - AFKer's. It's a problem in any game. When someone afk's here no bot takes over and the player's car just sits there         - Bit of a grind to buy anything in game. It's all cosmetic though         - 1 map, and only 1 gamemode. Early access woes. I hope they get at least 4 more maps and add a racing mode The game runs very smoothly for me, unlike some other reviewers. I haven't had any crashes or freezing issues. It's a free game! Try a few rounds, play each type of car to see what fits your play style.

Heavy Metal Machines is a 4vs4 team action racing game that mixes a heavy metal soundtrack with an action-packed Mad Max-inspired world. Basically, is a mix of Rock'n Roll Racing and Twisted Metal.Two teams compete in frantic battles to deliver the bomb to the opposing side's base. Each team has their own race track on their side of the map that the enemy team has to transport the bomb through and your job is to stop them from getting there, intercept the bomb from them, and turn around to race it to their side of the map. The team of four players have three roles that each one can fill: Transporter, Interceptor, and Support. The cars are very customizable and the game offer a lot of skills, you can access a wide variety of skills by trying out new characters, each offering four abilities for use in battle.Great intro and the tutorial is excellent. The soundtrack and the graphics are very good, I really liked it. Trying to match with others online took too long, but it's normal because the game is recent and have yet a low playerbase. You may also find some bugs, but it's normal. HMM with a nice and significant playerbase can be a successful game, and I'm not a big fan of racing games.

By ALL means, try the game out!This game is very fun, it has unique concepts and the overall mad-max sort of style is awesome to play with. However, for the actual gameplay, it's incredibly hard to actually gain bomb-control. For example, if the enemy has the bomb, there's very little chance you can actually gain control of the bomb. Cars are too tanky and abilities deal little to no damage. This game should be about CARNAGE! And destroying everyone!! But its hard to do that when you're up against a Transporter class with 500 Health and your abilities do about 10 damage each to it. I think cars should deal damage to eachother when running into eachother, death timers should be lower and it should be easier to get kills. The bomb should always be flying around the map amidst a rumble of players destroying eachother. Actually taking the bomb to the enemy base should be something incredibly hard to do. From my expierience, I can get it off the start, and drive it to the enemy base with little to no reprecussions apart from 5 damage a second from holding the bomb. For a game which is very fast paced, the fighting really isn't. The overall objective is way too easy to complete. This game has SO much potential, I just don't think it's being unleashed yet.

								I'm a pretty avid LoL and Smite player, and I really wanted to enjoy this game. It looked really fun when I watched Brofresco play it, and I can see how one day it would be in a proper release state (as opposed to early access) when it might be fun. But, for now, the game suffers from really severe balance issues: some big machines simply mow through an entire team, others are too nimble to even catch up with. I already realized after playing only a bit of this game that this was a big problem. Queue times were fine, interface is sort of hard on the eyes but that's fine because I found everything. Currently, I'd request that 1) you allow people to see the abilities of a machine BEFORE entering a game 2) you allow for a mode where you can test out new cars without having to battle other cars (sandbox or custom game) 3) matches are too short and feel too one-sided, so although I realize this is the hardest to fix, balance the machines out more and finally 4) stop trying to bandwagon the current MOBA boom. Some of those tropes feel cheap and I would suggest an approach like HOTS has done, where it has taken big MOBA elements like the upgrade store and revamped it as an XP pool which gives intermittent buffs. This encourages team play, farming, objectives, and kills, a lot more than the "metal" system does, which outside of "killing other machines" is impossible to come by.This idea is super cool. I want to see this game work. But right now it's mediocre at best.You guys gotta put some elbow grease in, starting right about now, because this has tons of potential and now is the time to show that.

								MOBA meets Rock and Roll Racing in a nice little package with unique characters and abilities.I have to say this about this game, however.  The way you go about upgrading is very similar to Awesomenauts, in that you're limited in what you can purchase per weapon.  The breakdown:Graphics: 4.5 - From what I've seen, the graphics are polished, stylized to represent a post-apocolyptic setting, and the effects are nothing to sneeze at.  Everything is well represented, though you might get a little confused with what's going on with several things happening.  You may also get stuck a few times not knowing where you're facing.Sound 4 - I just love the roar of the engines, but the announcer.....let's just say he's no Larry from Rock and Roll Racing.  I applaud the fact that some of the lines are lifted from R&RR ("The stage is set.  The green flag drops."  "Let the carnage begin!"), however, some of it seems out of place.  For example, there really is no race other than racing to get to the bomb first, but it becomes a matter of taking out opponents, and, again, it's not about coming in first in a race.  Other than that, I like how they're trying to trigger my nostalgia from the SNES/Genesis classic racing game.Controls 4 - I have to knock this down a bit.  My XBox 360 controller just won't respond well to the game at all.  I can't move forward, only reverse.  Left stick tells me that it should work, but doesn't.  There's no way to accelerate with the controller.  That said, the keyboard/mouse controls work farily well, but do get some getting used to.  I suggest going into practice mode a few times to get accustom to them.Gameplay 5 - I like a good MOBA game, and I enjoy it even better when they try something new.  This is a mixture of automobile battle and CTF (or payload from TF2).  It's a fun idea, and I hope other game modes come out for this.  I can see a load of other fun games they could add to spice things up.Overall 4.25 - I enjoyed what I've played so far, and hope to actually try online multiplayer (as of this writing, I've only had experience with practice mode).  However, I can see this being an engaging, fun little game for any MOBA player or racing fan.  I suggest trying it, as it's free, and...."LET THE CARNAGE BEGIN!"UPDATE: Controller support works, but I do have one other gripe.  At the start of online multiplayer, a system to sync every player before the race starts is of major importance.  I know my system is a bit of a potato now adays, but I'm able to load and play, but during multiplayer games, the game throws me in when the battle has begun.  It's a bit of a hiccup to catch up, but I still managed to do something in the end.  Something for the devs to think about.
